message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most likely cause of sudden death in a young athlete is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which can lead to systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve. Narrowing of the left main coronary artery or a ventricular septal defect can also cause sudden death, but they are less common than HCM. Bicuspid aortic valve would not cause sudden death, but it is associated with aortic stenosis, which can cause sudden death in extreme cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden death during physical activity suggests sudden cardiac arrest, which is often caused by hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve is a common finding in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Narrowing of the left main coronary artery causes angina and myocardial infarction but may not result in sudden death. Bicuspid aortic valve and ventricular septum defect may cause heart murmurs, but are less likely to lead to sudden cardiac arrest in a previously healthy young adult.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden collapse without any previous history strongly suggests sudden cardiac arrest, which can be caused by various cardiac abnormalities. Among the options, systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve is strongly associated with sudden cardiac arrest in young adults. Narrowing of the left main coronary artery, bicuspid aortic valve, and ventricular septum defect are also associated with sudden cardiac arrest but are not as strongly associated with it as the systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient collapsed suddenly, which suggests the cause of death to be cardiac-related. Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve can cause sudden cardiac death in young people, whereas the other options typically do not present with sudden death.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient collapsed suddenly, which suggests a cardiac cause. Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve can cause sudden cardiac death, especially in young athletes, and is often associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Narrowing of the left main coronary artery can also cause sudden cardiac death, but it's less common in young patients. Bicuspid aortic valve and ventricular septum defect are typically congenital abnormalities and would have been detected earlier in life.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden collapse and lack of pulse suggest sudden cardiac death. Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve can cause obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can lead to sudden cardiac death. The other options do not typically cause sudden cardiac death in young individuals.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve (SAM) can lead to sudden cardiac death in young adults during intense exercise, and is most likely the cause of this patient's collapse while playing basketball. The other options may also lead to sudden cardiac death, but are less likely in a previously healthy 20-year-old.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve (SAM) can cause sudden cardiac arrest and is common in young athletes. Narrowing of the left main coronary artery, bicuspid aortic valve, and ventricular septal defects are all potential sources of cardiac abnormalities, but SAM is the most likely cause of sudden cardiac arrest in a young athlete.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden collapse and lack of pulse or respiratory effort suggest sudden cardiac death. Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve (SAM) is a known cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes. The other options are not typically associated with sudden cardiac death.

Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve (SAM) can lead to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which is the most common cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes. The other options are all possible causes of sudden cardiac death but are less common in young athletes.
